FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: anhydrous ammonia storage tank, nurse tanks, relief valves, plumbing, pump

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

For further information contact Michael Peterson, Safety & Regulations manager.

I.  The facility policy
   A.  The owners, managers and employees of Sweetland Ag Tech LLC., Muscatine, Ia are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire dept., LEPC, or other authorities, to migrate any release and to minimize the impact of the release on people and the environment.  Our company policy would be to shutoff any emergency valves that is possible for us to get to.  Evacuate anypersons in the way of harm.

II.  Facility info
   A.  The primary activity at the facility is the handling of anhydrous ammonia for sale to farmers.

   B.  Anhydrous Ammonia is received, and distributed for application on crops as fertilizer nutrients.

III.  Worst case release scenario and the alternative release scenario.
   A.  The worst case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the storage tank over a ten minute period.  The maximum quantity release would be 79,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the tank at 85% capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the toxic endpoints is 1.06 miles.

    B.  The alternative release scenario is based on release from a break in a transfer hose.  The distance to the toxic endpoint is 0.59 miles.  To keep mitigation to a minimum we would shutoff all emergency valves as possible, call fire dept., and keep area evacuated.

IV.  The accidental release prevention program.
    A.  The facility has implanted the provisions of the safety requirments for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia, K-61, published by the American Standards Institute Inc.

    B.  The facility has implanted the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration, 29CFR 1910.111, Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Due to the fact that we are inspected annually by IDALS,

we do manual and visual inspections periodically to maintain an accident free facility.

V.  The five year accident history.
    A.  There has been no accidental release of anhydrous ammonia that has caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility, nor have resulted in any off site deaths, injury, evacuations, sheltering, property damage, or environmental damage.

VI.  The emergency response program.
    A.  The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38.

    B.  The facility has provided th the state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right to know information as required under SARA title III (EPCRA).

    C.  This facility has a emergency action plan including pre emergency planning and employee training.  We at Sweetland Ag Tech take pride in personal and plant safety by conducting plant inspections, annul classroom and hands on training.  Also inspection by IDALS.

VII.  Planned changes to improve safety.
    A.  Safety improvements is an ongoing process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to access the maintenance of safe conditions and evaluate employee training.  There are no specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations at this point in time.
